PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NO. 2

SASKATCHEWAN HISTORY ASSOCIATION
PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation as to the questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because individuals who have lived in various parts of the province may have different experiences. It is therefore suggested that each person should answer the questions according to his own experience.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who have lived in Western Canada for at least five years. If there is any doubt about whether or not someone should be included, please consult the interviewer.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They made us welcome when we came. We had a hard time until my father got settled in a homestead.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With my family.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By train (The Banffian) from Banff to Watella (W.W.T.) then by railroad car to Watella (W.W.T.) then by horse-drawn cart to my grandfather's home at High Cliff.

14. What incidences of the journey do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Trying to stay on the slanted seats of the coach during a cow bell when we were stopped at a station in Ontario, also finding a place to have dinner when we arrived at Quinter. I have no much of the general language spoken.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

With my grandfather's some of his family.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

High Cliff, Saskatchewan.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

The only other place I have lived in Canada is Bear Creek, Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

I started working as a laborer before coming to Canada. After that, I helped my father on the farm and to build the house, break land, and the owner helped me to dig wells. I also helped my neighbors with their work. I had no problem doing other chores connected with farming.

On Sept. 18th, 1909, I came came by train from Idaho to Montana. We had to walk all night through the snow and mud. We arrived in Montana the next day. It was very cold and we had to sleep outside.
